description: The capital of Taiwan, a cultural and political hub known for Taipei 101 and vibrant night markets.
Taiwan’s most populous municipality surrounding Taipei, with diverse districts and scenic mountains.
An industrial and tech hub, home to Taiwan’s main international airport and growing urban centers.
A central city famous for its cultural institutions, night markets, and gateway to Sun Moon Lake.
Taiwan’s oldest city, rich in temples and history, often called the cultural capital of Taiwan.
A major port city in southern Taiwan, known for its harbor, arts scene, and Love River.
A northern port city near Taipei, famous for seafood markets and coastal scenery.
Known as Taiwan’s Silicon Valley, hosting the Hsinchu Science Park and major semiconductor companies.
Gateway to Alishan mountain range, known for tea plantations and scenic railways.
Seat of Changhua County, known for traditional culture and agriculture.
Seat of Yunlin County, known for agriculture and traditional Taiwanese culture.
Eastern coastal city, base for exploring Taroko Gorge and indigenous culture.
Main city of the Penghu Islands, noted for fishing, temples, and island tourism.
Seat of Miaoli County, blending Hakka culture with mountainous landscapes.
Central inland city, gateway to Sun Moon Lake and mountainous landscapes.
Southern city near Kenting National Park, known for tropical climate and beaches.
County-administered city in Chiayi County, known for traditional temples.
A city in Miaoli County, blending traditional industries with modern development.
A northeastern city famous for hot springs, traditional festivals, and coastal landscapes.
Rapidly growing city in Hsinchu County, closely tied to the tech industry.
A laid-back city on Taiwan’s southeast coast, known for indigenous heritage and natural beauty.
